qas.question: What do some non-single-sex polychaetes do?
What are most polychaetes lacking for reproduction?
How do some annelids get a one-time chance at a better spawning spot?

answers.text: the rear of the body splits off and becomes a separate individual

qas.question: What do all non-single-sex polychaetes do?
What are no polychaetes lacking for reproduction?

plausible_answers.text: the rear of the body splits off and becomes a separate individual

qas.question: How do some annelids get a three-time chance at a better spawning spot?
How many polychaetes breed an infinite amount of times?

context: <b6_0>Some<b6_0/> polychaetes breed only once in their lives, while others breed almost continuously or through several breeding seasons. While most polychaetes remain of one sex all their lives, a significant percentage of species are full hermaphrodites or <a0_0><b3_0>change sex<b3_0/><a0_0/> during their lives. Most polychaetes whose reproduction has been studied lack <a1_0><b4_0>permanent gonads<b4_0/><a1_0/>, and it is uncertain how they produce ova and sperm. In a few species <a2_0><b5_0>the rear of the body splits off and becomes a separate individual<b5_0/><a2_0/> that lives just long enough to swim to a suitable environment, usually near the surface, and spawn.
